replies.text: Honestly, folks should just double on any stock the DOJ accuses of monopoly. If its a good enough moat for the DOJ, it is for me.
I invested in V a couple years ago its been performed great so far. Exposed to economic down turn and with such a large market share its growth is limited by growth of world economies.

To me visa and Mastercard present a massive risk because they have such heavy profit margin and are ripe for disruption. Idk when it will happen, but at some point they will be disrupted and the premium their stocks have will crumble. Because of the moat they maintain a fairly high PE, but if its breached not only will profits shrink, PE ratio might go from 30 to like 10. Microsoft for example has a pretty big most on office, but still works pretty hard to keep the product well ahead technically. Visa kinda just sits on their ass.

Big moat. Was this not obvious?

I used to be a big Visa fan for its moat, but with the arrival of new payment systems I have exited V as an investment. They are relying on an outdated network system compared to what can be achieved with new technologies. There are increasingly more payment alternatives appearing, I doubt that Visa will be able to increase or even hold their current market share. Also business have to pay a percentage of their proceeds and as such have no loyalty to Visa. If a different payment system can provide a similar service but cheaper, Visas downfall could be quite fast.

The issue is the credit card rewardspoints. Getting 2 back to use your card and then paying off your balance, puts money in wealthier peoples pockets. Its like free money to someone that doesnt need it. They are able to pay it off every month. Poorer people cannot pay off every month, so the points are meaningless. This drives up costs for poorer people because now merchants add on 2 to their goods to make up for the card processing fees. So its sort of a hidden benefit for richer people. Once the government eliminates any type of reward for using credit cards, both Visa and Mastercard will fall.
The Bitcoin Network provides an alternative to traditional finance rails such as Visas network. If bitcoin continues to grow in adoption it might not be a good idea to invest in Visa long term.

The ChickenEgg problem described in OPs excerpts could be wiped away if with chipped US ID cards. For example, Norways ID card is their drivers license, debit card, and credit card. They have a state bank account, but private groups can also tap into the ID cards chip to verify their identity. If the US or US states started doing that, everymany Americans would immediately have a trusted card that could be used by Visa, MC, etc. Similarly, nearly everyone has a smart phone with Apple Pay and Google Wallet. Its only a matter of time before they make their own cards and immediately cut into that market. That said, if the US or any states were actually interested in ending Visas monopoly, theyd have already started down that path. So, I honestly dont believe the US government cares about monopolies at all. It will put on a show, and then do nothing, just as it always does in these monopoly cases. Disclosure Im somewhat ignorant on this topic, and this is not investing advice. I have no stake in V or any credit card processor.

Some people may luck out in deflation. For example, if someone owned 50 of their investments in bonds and tbills, the price of the bonds would go up as rates are lowered to zero percent again. During deflation when nobody wants to spend money or borrow at 3 to buy a home, the bond holders could sell some highpriced bonds to the QE banks when bond prices are high and rates are low, and buy houses at bargain prices during times of super low mortgage rates. This is why its good to keep a few bonds in your investments because the next recession or depression cycle could unexpectedly appear at any time. Good quality long term maturity bonds help hedge recession and low rates. Tbills help hedge high rates set by the Fed.

Deflation is bad for the economy because it discourages spending, investment, and consumption at the macro level. Sure, deflation would benefit inelastic essentials like food, but in a service based economy that relies heavily on capital investment and consumption, 8 deflation over several years would have disastrous effects. Deflation increases the purchasing power per dollar, which on the surface sounds good until you realize it also means wages will go down. It also discourages investment at all levels since rampant deflation would create a sentiment that its better to hold off since you can get more for your money later on. Why take the risk investing in the market or investing in RD if you could earn 8 just having the money sit in a bank account. High deflation would also decimate people with mortgages or loans since the payments on the loan remain the same while the purchasing power per dollar and their wages would be going down. So their monthly mortgage payments would be going up over time in real terms. High inflation is also bad, but a small amount of inflation like 2 benefits everyone because it means spending and investment is encouraged since money is losing 2 of its value if its doing nothing, and payments on mortgages and loans go down in real terms over long periods. Overall, deflation or zero inflation creates a culture of saving like in Japan and a small amount of inflation creates a culture of spendinginvesting.

Literally 100 of economists from across the ideological spectrum would tell you an 8 deflation rate would be disastrous. Everyone and every business would hold onto their money because its value would grow just by doing nothing. Investments would stall, consumer spending would drop precipitously beyond bare necessities, hiring would freeze, wages would fall, jobs would increasingly be lost, and economic growth would reverse. In a lot of ways Boeing basically sounds like another example of what Steve Jobs said decades ago about why once innovative companies tend to fall apart and cease to be innovative overtime. Early on its the techies and innovators who make the company grow by creating the new technologyproducts, and improving on the previous creations. But then as the company grows bigger the people who increase the sales and make the company more money are the marketers, so more and more of the upper ranks of the company get filled with marketers and money people, and less with the tech people who built the company from the ground up. And without the innovatorsetc. who designed and built the products running things the company stagnates and ceases to innovate. And then eventually someone else more innovative comes along and topples them with a newer invention. Boeing has clearly been hallowed out the marketers, but we still need someone new to come along and topple them with newer innovations in the space.

One possible solution could be for Boeing to spin off its military aviation business from its commercial aerospace operations. This could also ensure that Boeing doesnt try to pay off its fines to Uncle Sam by increasing the price tag for the combat aircraft it sells to the Pentagon. Breaking up the company was an idea floated back in early 2020 when the issues over the 737 MAX were first coming into focus. As 247 Wall Street reported at the time, Boeings defense, space and security businesses have as their primary customers U.S. and overseas governments. The divisions backlog for defense and services is 62 billion, of which 30 is from customers outside America. Revenue from these operations is almost certain to be steady or to rise. The same cant be said more than four years later for Boeings commercial business. Breaking up the company might be the only way to save Boeing, and to ensure the Department of Defense can continue work with one of its biggest contractors.

What I said was Software is a different level of complexity due to being public facing. I used security to illustrate that point. Software grows in complexity like many engineering systems nonlinearly as lines of code increase and various projects connect, which they frequently have to, for software to function. Why does this make it harder? Mainly due to the fact that you cannot easily separate software systems like you might separate mechanical systems like HVAC from landing gear. There are more parts to software call them libraries, function, methods, projects or whatever you want and they have to interconnect and communicate to the tune of millions of lines of code supported by thousands of programmers all over the place. To make matters worse, we will open the software to Joe Schmoe and his merry band of vacationers who each have a different smartphone made by god knows who from whatever country which may or may not have the latest security patches, running whatever app written by some dude in his garage, all connected to the planes internet network... what can go wrong? This is the problem with public facing. Never mind the infinite number of attack vectors just for being online exposing any vulnerability to the millions of lines of code running on all these devices... Last, planes are not public facing. They are literally gated and monitored at all times by ports, police and other agencies. You dont have to design a plane in such a way that someone cant steal the air bags... that isnt a realistic worry. But you do have to design software exactly like that to prevent privacy data from leaking or worse, plane systems get exposed due to some idiot network engineering design... Software has no port guards, or police to physically secure the medium. Its just a programmer vs bad guys and dumb dumb Joe Schmoe. Here is an interesting factoid. Did you know that the 747 has over 8mil lines of code just for the avionics and online support systems? Total flight software is something like 15mil lines of code.

Some people believe that when Wall Street Firms especially big banks like Morgan Stanley say to buy something that theyre ready to dump their bags and its time to sell. Theres controversy about how some of them have both a ratings branch that rates stocks and sets price targets, and a branch that manages clients money. Legally they have to be separate from each other, but theres been plenty of times in the past when its stirred up controversy where one part of the company says Stock ABC is a great buy, while the other part is selling out of the same company. This is part of where the sentiment that its time to get out of a stock when Wall Street recommends buying it came from.

I was at Connect today. Tried the RayBans. Folks underestimate how much of a technological lead Meta has. They used only 16,000 of their H100 gpus to pretrain llama. They have 600,000 of these gpus. They open sourced their fully sharded data parallel training software. Theyve subtley commoditized and collapsed the nascent LLM startups, while gaining a decade long lead in the hardest hardware development ever which is indeed those next gen Orion glasses. They spent a billion dollars acquiring the neural interfaces company that developed that EMG wristband. There is quite honestly no company ahead of Meta right now in AI OR hardware and certainly there is value in that

The real key here for stock investors is the AR glasses. Problem is, I believe truly viable AR glasses are still at least 10 years away after seeing all the demos today. Its impressive that they could get a 69 degree FOV with waveguide technology. The big downside is that you have 3 things that go together with this device. The power puck, the glasses and the wristband thing. Its not just glasses. Its 3 things. The glasses are too thick for prime time. They will have to figure out how to chop that thickness almost in half, which could be impossible. They also need to dramatically increase the resolution. Increasing the FOV would be great, but I think theyre pretty much hitting a hard limit with it. Still a solid decade away from a real AR glasses contender

And that makes the weight issue described above even worse. 4 What if I already wear glasses? Do you expect me to just wear two pairs of glasses at once? And on top of all that a smartphone can already do all of the good things you mentioned, without all of the flaws that I mentioned.

Netflix had an app for a while, but I dont think it works anymore. Youtube VR is great, and you can either watch normal videos on a screen you can move and resize to whatever you want, or you can find the actual 3600 videos. Theres a Meta app that has a lot of videos to watch as well. If you want to watch Disney or Netflix, I think you still can from the browser, which you can also resize and move around. Of course, you can always use the normal video player app to watch movies you downloaded to the device. The watching experience is great, especially on the Quest 3. Its just a shame there isnt more support from the developers when it comes to the Quest apps.

I dont wear glasses but I live with someone who does. She is able to use the Quest 3 with her glasses on and she says its pretty comfortable. You can also get prescription lenses that simply anap in over the built in lenses for like 50 on Zenni, which we havent received yet but I imagine will be just like playing without glassescontacts on at all but still have the clear vision.

Watching media in a VR headset is a really cool experience, but apps like Netflix either arent good or arent available in the headset, so you often have to use the browser for them. Thats another case where having a high powered PC makes the headset better because you can just mirror your computer screen. Theres exercise and productivity uses for it, but I dont have much experience with that. Some people love it, but both those cases work better if you can see your environment. Unfortunately the passthrough is just not quite there yet to make it usable for long periods of time for me personally. Thats why Meta is making glasses so you dont need passthrough. Even though theres benefits, its hard to convince people to do their entertainment, exercise, and productivity inside of VRAR when the drawbacks are so apparent. Again, I love my Quest 3 though and recommend it to people, but theres a ways to go before it will get widespread adoption. Itll get there, Meta is doing a great job imo in innovating in this space.

Theres a lot of reason to think that. Take your first example, traffic directions. They have to figure out exactly where youre looking and seamlessly embed the directions into it to make it not drive you insane. If its just the same map as the phone but overlaid, youre creating a blind spot. If there is even the slightest lag where the arrow drags, its going to make you crazy and cause problems. Thats before we even begin to talk about the liability of something impeding vision while driving. Having played significantly with OCR Optical character recognition trying to apply it for a project at work, I have no faith at all it could translate the text on random signs into another language. It likely wont even get the original language right. The AR art displays is an interesting idea though. I could also see it being used as an enhancement for Pokemon GO style games. The other thing you have to think about is that a lot of this processing would need to be done locally by the glasses. If it requires too much processing and has to be sent to the cloud and back, the lag is going to mess with you pretty bad. I think youre on the right track for use cases, but I think your ideas are way ahead of where the technology actually is.

About translating the text on signs our phones can already do that, the advantage of the AR glasses would be that you do not have to occupy one of your hands for it. Dude, I write code for a living. I challenge your ChatGpT bear post with my bull case gpt post. We can do this all day. The bull case for NVIDIA, despite the potential cracks in the AI scaling hypothesis, remains compelling due to a number of factors 1. AI Beyond Scaling Diversification of Architectures While the scaling hypothesis may face limitations, NVIDIA is not solely reliant on larger models for growth. The shift towards diverse architecturessuch as edge computing, federated learning, and more efficient, adaptable modelsstill heavily depends on advanced hardware. NVIDIAs innovation in custom AI chips and specialized GPUs for varied workloads ensures that it continues to dominate, even as the industry pivots away from pure scale. 2. AI Software Ecosystem NVIDIAs CUDA platform, AI software stack, and Deep Learning SDKs offer essential tools for AI developers. These tools are deeply integrated across the AI research and enterprise ecosystems, which means that even if scaling slows, NVIDIAs software dominance secures its position as a key player. Moreover, AI companies are dependent on NVIDIAs endtoend platform, from training to deployment, and this dependency is unlikely to change even if the emphasis shifts from scale to smarter, more efficient architectures. 3. Enterprise and Data Center Expansion Even beyond researchdriven AI, enterprise adoption of AI is growing rapidly. Companies across industriesfinance, healthcare, and logisticsare integrating AI into their operations, and this trend fuels continued demand for highperformance computing HPC solutions. NVIDIAs foothold in data centers is a major asset, as demand for AIpowered insights and automation continues to grow. The company is positioned to benefit from AIdriven automation, which is expected to scale massively in the next few years. 4. AI in Autonomous Systems NVIDIAs leadership in autonomous vehicles, robotics, and other AIdriven automation solutions offers another strong growth avenue. The companys Drive platform for autonomous driving and its investments in industrial robots and AIpowered edge devices place NVIDIA in a favorable position as automation accelerates across multiple industries. 5. Gaming and Virtual Worlds Metaverse While AI remains the main growth driver, NVIDIAs core business in gaming is still robust, and its investment in the metaverseparticularly via its Omniverse platformis positioned for future growth. The convergence of AI, VR, and GPUpowered graphics in virtual worlds will open up new revenue streams, ensuring that NVIDIAs hardware remains in demand across various sectors beyond traditional AI use cases. 6. AI Custom Silicon and Competition NVIDIA is investing heavily in custom silicon AIspecific hardware. The Grace CPU and Grace Hopper Superchip, alongside nextgen H100 GPUs, cater to evolving needs in AI and HPC. These chips optimize AI workloads and enable costeffective scaling, keeping NVIDIA ahead of competitors like AMD and Intel. 7. AI as a Deflationary Force The massive potential of AI to create efficiencies across industries means that the macroeconomic environment will continue to favor companies like NVIDIA. As AI proves its worth in reducing operational costs, improving supply chains, and automating workflows, NVIDIAs role in supplying the necessary infrastructure will keep demand strong. Conclusion Bull Case for NVDA Despite possible challenges to the scalability hypothesis, NVIDIA remains a key enabler of the AI economy. Its leadership in hardware and software, expansion into new markets like autonomous vehicles, and diverse revenue streams provide a strong foundation for continued growth. Even if the AI bubble bursts in some areas, the underlying technological advancements and enterprise applications are likely to sustain NVIDIAs trajectory.

I dont like Starbucks, never really have. But its an interesting thought exercise If you were given 85 million signing bonus plus an even sicker compensation package, what changes would you make to prove you were worth it? Myself, my forte is in making services and products undeniably great, and letting quality drive the business side. Not to the exclusion of shrewd business strategy and tactics, but I just put the priority on having something great that people want, and letting that be the flywheel. So for me, Id finally accept the incredibly common perception that Starbucks actual coffee is mediorceburnt. Weve seen others publicly and with humility accept and fix that... see McCafe, DPZ, CMG, etc. For those who say you cant make that change! I say you cant expect big changes unless you make changes. For those who say the old is good enough, I point to the stock performance as proof its not. Id be the best quality and go with a nicer but more broadly appealing taste profile. As SBUX, wed have the scale and resources to get the very best while still benefitting from scale. Im not sweating about margins in the first wave of this transformation because frankly a drink that you can charge a food price for suggests margin not be a problem over time. Second Id embrace some tech. People are kind of over the myth that you need a slow paced barista teasing out your drink for five minutes. CafeLux and Nespresso have shown you can get 90 of great coffee or cold drinks without lifting a finger. Id seek to take the best of learnings from those and apply them to a faster service model. Maybe that means the barista role is to focus on the part only they can do, and do best, but spares them from the other 90. Thats still TBD, but the goal of pumping out the actual drinks, cold or hot, WAY faster is not negotiable. In parallel wed have some kind of highly mediamentionable value choices. Perhaps not the 99 cent coffee that every pundit thinks they were the first to think of, since it would only be reinforcing the oldbad taste and also trading short term traffic surge which isnt the problem for weaker reputation and perception. But maybe some quick and easy 3 buck options that are enough to generate broad public knowledge. The taste and speed have to be newsworthy upgrades. The value options must also generate a buzz, but should be aligned with supporting not undermining the first two priorities. There would be more phases, but the emergency mission would be whole new supply and taste, combined with huge efficiency boost by automating that which can be. That phase alone probably justifies yesterdays 20 billion move.

It is actually more nuanced than that. Yes, for certain acts like agreeing with your competitor to set a price, you dont need to prove consumer harm. However, for anything that is not per se antitrust, you do need to prove consumer harm. This is because of court precedent and not cause of the law itself. The reason for this is that, read at face value, the act prohibits all contracts because what every contract restricts trade in some way. That is the point of a contract. The court is obviously reticent to read the law that way since if they did, all contracts would need to be thrown out. So, for some antitrust claims you need to prove consumer harm and for some others, you dont

Then, they would need to begin charging high fees for their RD to all the other phone brands. But the biggest players would just build off of the last free version of Android. Google play services would no longer be relevant to phones, so Samsungs OS likely becomes an isolated platform worth targeting like iPhone, with their own App Store taking 30. Over time, diverging operating systems would mean apps will only target the biggest players. With no Google services, the Android company loses relevance. The next big app is only available on Samsung Galaxy and iPhone because they have the largest market shares. Small phone manufacturers like Nothing and OnePlus can no longer compete without apps, they cant afford the RD of their own OS, and neither can the Android company without income from services nor big manufacturer license fees. Chrome does do things with your data that other browsers dont do. Just as with Gmail, Chrome collects your user ID and device ID in too many categories. Unlike Safari, Edge and Firefox, Chrome says it links all harvested data to devices and individuals. Safari collects but doesnt link browsing history, usage data and locations to users. Neither Firefox nor Edge link usage data. But Chrome says it collects all those data fields and links all of them to user identities. This isnt complicated. The fact is that Chrome collects more data than any of the other browsers, yet is the only one that doesnt appear to collect any data that isnt linked to user identities. This is a much more shocking illustration of the different philosophies at play. Chrome hasnt even attempted to protect its users privacy in this way. This isnt about specific data fields, this is about an overarching attitude to privacy. It is technically true Chrome does not directly make revenue for Google because it is free to use. But this is a bit disingenuous as an assertion because Google sells access to data collected by Chrome to advertisers, who use it to target you with ads all across the internet. This leads to undisclosed fucktons of revenue. The biggest change is Ad Topics, a.k.a. the Topics API if youre a huge nerd whos been following this stuff for years. With Topics, Chrome will keep track of all the websites youre looking at and sort you into a variety of categories. This tracking happens in your browser and the data stays on your device. Neither Google nor anyone else gets to see your browsing history or learn anything about you as an individual throughout this process. Websites and advertising companies will know theres a person interested in a certain Topic, but they wont be able to tell who you are specifically. Edit formatting

Theyre slow on agreeing to standards because standardizing your operating systems is hard. The web as it exists today, while impressive, is a mess. You know what happens today when Android or iOS find a faster way to do things? They delete the old way, and maybe that means your app only works on certain versions of the software, but now its faster, more secure, and easy to maintain. What happens when we find a better way to do something on the web? Well we have to wait 3 years for all the browsers to come to a consensus, then they cant get rid of the old way because it would break all the existing websites. Its kind of like Windows vs Mac. Mac is very consistent, fast, etc, because it has been able to cut away the worst parts of itself. The things that sucked on a 2010 Mac dont exist on one today. But Windows does the opposite. They keep around lots of old things, so you can still run your copy of quickbooks 2007 or quake 3. Yes, its more compatible, but they are now beholden to those dead standards and can no longer change. These are massive problems and its not as easy as big tech wont let me use WASM.

The sad truth is despite the governments good intentions, they really dont know what they are doing in the overall, long term picture. It give uniformity etc. It was a wasted time to breakup Microsoft as their smartphone folded thanks to AndroidiOS, Apple Mac OS became a dominate force in the computer market, and IE went extinct like the dodo bird and even embraced chromium. bing and duckduckgo became challengers to google search. Google hangouts folded to facebook, reddit, instagram, etc. What they fail to understand is that tech is a shifting landscape, if they fail to innovate, like Nvida eating Intels breakfast, lunch, and dinner they will become obsolete. Because others dont have the market share of Google? The reason why Google has to stop such deals are not the deals but their position that they already have. Its not an anticompetitive deal if youre the smaller player.
No in 2020 Your link is for a more recent update.

What you linked is for new Android devices The search choice screen is a screen presented to Android users in the EU setting up their devices for the first time or after performing a factory reset. What Im speaking about is OS independent Choice screens. Google plans to introduce more choice screens based on user research, testing, and industry feedback. You will see the additional screens when your setup an Android phones, and soon they will also be incorporated into Chrome for desktop and iOS devices as well.

Well in any case, people are choosing to use Google despite the EUs regulations. In February 2020, prior to the rollout, Googles mobile search market share was 97.38, according to statcounter. Between then and January 2021, it hovered between 97.41 March 2020 and 97.16 January 2021. As an antitrust remedy, the choice screen has not only failed to make the search market a more competitive space, it may even be reinforcing Googles dominant position. They deserve to be fined and taxed, but not broken up. Europe could also choose to do what China did and block them out entirely. But Europe has no good alternative to replace them with. And Google has more user share in Europe than in the US, like I said before. People are choosing Google because they like it, simple as that.

As I said that assuming you know more than the Google executives that thought paying billions to Apple, Samsung and Mozilla is worth it. EU and DoJ are targeting different goals. EU has nothing against Google as long as the follow data privacy rules and gives other companies a fair chance. EU could not even break them up since its an US company. The DoJ has just decided that Google is a monopoly and acting anticompetitive. Fines dont change the fact that they are a monopoly. Thats why they suggest a break up.

The cofounders have the real power at Google, not the executives. I didnt say that I know better, I said that if they are forced to stop paying then we get an experiment to see what happens. DOJ is going to have to prove it to a jury. Lets see what happens.

replies.text: You dont see it when you look at the revenue, but UpWorks growth has been declining and pretty much has come to a halt. Gross services volume is basically the same as it was a year ago. Revenue is only up because they keep increasing the take rate. 19 of what the clients pay now goes to UpWork. Their revenue guidance for Q3 is less than what they made in Q2. So they might enter a phase of negative growth now. Caused by declining usage which cannot be offset by further increasing the take rate. They keep focussing on enterprise deals and neglect the marketplace experience. Although the marketplace is the 6x bigger business. Clients who use the marketplace still get 3 ! invoices and receipts per week ! even if they just work with one freelancer. Who wouldnt want to add 19 to their freelancer cost and the hassle to add 12 documents per month to their tax paperwork? TlDr They focus on their sales team, neglect the product, make it more and more expensive, usage growth declines. They still have a great starting point as the market leader in work marketplaces. But unless they change the approach, I think nothing will come out of it. If the business slips away, my hope is that a new, more product oriented CEO will come into play.
Assymetric to the downside.
Ive been on Upwork for years It is straight ass these days

Thank you for sharing your thoughts. I do agree that there is still work to do, however, the take rate is much much lower compared to Fiverr. I do think the invoicing part can be improved, I know theres a giant project in regards to the VAT calculation.

Im not saying the increase in take rate is necessarily bad. But it is also not what can make up for a decline in users in the long term. Fiverrs market cap is 30 smaller than UpWorks. So it is not a proven way forward that can be a role model for UpWork. Also their business is different. Average spent per buyer is 4x smaller on Fiverr compared to UpWork. When you commission a onetime job like a logo, it doesnt matter if you pay 100 or 130. That wont make you take the job off the platform. But when you work with a freelancer on a constant basis, you start to think about why you pay UpWork every month too. Because the only thing you get for it is the invoicing. And when that invoicing is done super badly 12 monthly documents instead of 1, 4 monthly payments instead of 1 you will think hard if you really want to continue using that service.

In my opinion, UpWork is there not only to connect the freelancer with the client but also to provide trust. it ensures that if the work gets done, the freelancer gets paid. In case of any disputes, an UpWork representative steps in. Taking a contract outside of UpWork is against their terms and conditions unless the fee is paid. Yes, clientsfreelancers can agree to continue working outside of the platform. However, if theres a dispute at any point in time, one party will be unsatisfied. In addition, both parties are back to square one, the client needs to find a new freelancer, and the freelancer needs to find a new client.

True. They offer more than just invoicing. Still the invoicing is done badly and that hurts a lot. Im not sure the other services make up for it. And currently the numbers make it seem that the concept is not working. Gross services volume was about 4B in 2022, about 4B in 2023 and might be even lower this year. Is there reason to expect that this stagnationdecline will stop and turn into growth again?

I focus on the long run, and there I expect Increase in the number of freelancers Demand for freelancers to increase UpWork has reported an increase in enterprise clients. This isnt much reflected in the revenue, and I have a feeling this is due to the terms offered. I wouldnt be surprised if they have a free trial for a certain period, that doesnt generate any significant revenue for UpWork in the short run.

Where can we see that the number of freelancers and the demand for freelancers are increasing? On UpWork, there have been 872K active clients in Q1 and 868K in Q2. Thats a decline. I dont see that they reported an increase in enterprise clients. Where can I find that info? All I see in the investor presentation is enterprise revenue. And that also declined. From 26.6M in Q1 to 26.3M in Q2. Despite them spending 47M on sales and marketing in Q2.

The active clients is an important metric. However, comparing Q2 vs. Q1 is misleading due to holidays. Every year, there is decline in Q2 vs Q1. Instead, compare it vs. Q2 the previous year. The enterprise number was mentioned in the earnings call, and is also in the 10Q report. Lastly, the sales and marketing is decreasing over time allowing for higher margins. This is not only for the enterprise clients, but for all.

I dont see the number of enterprise clients in any of their documents. What is it? Maybe you are referring to their number for new enterprise clients? That does not tell us if the overall number is increasing or decreasing.

Yes, indeed, the new enterprise clients. This number in Q2 is higher than in Q1. However, I do not focus too much on this, given that the size of the enterprise clients isnt disclosed. This is why I find the active clients a more relevant number.

So the numbers tell a clear story, right? Usage growth has died down to zero. As seen in gross services volume and active users. And with the guidance of 6 revenue for Q3, it stands to be expected that usage will start shrinking now. Despite over a hundred million Dollars spent on sales and marketing per year. My interpretation UpWorks service is good at the beginning of the user journey. To match buyers and sellers. But then it becomes a chore. Because of the weekly invoice cycle and the separate invoicing from sellers and UpWork. That makes it an 8x worse solution than direct seller to buyer invoices. UpWork gained a massive amount of users during covid. And now those users abandon the service. Its a long way down to precovid levels. It can make the business decline for years. On the upside, UpWork might have the potential to become as big as the other market place leaders. Amazon, Uber, Booking, AirBnB, Shopify etc are all orders of magnitude larger than UpWork and I dont see a reason the leading work market place shouldnt become as big as those. But I think that would require a shift in the way UpWork is run. As the current approach to growth is not working. As can be seen in the numbers.

I am not sure if the invoicing would change, and to what extent. If you are a freelancer, it is good to be paid weekly instead of monthly. As for the user growth, it isnt actually declining. The of active clients is growing. Last year, they announced a change in their fee structure. It used to be multitier 20, then 10, then 5. So, the larger the contract, the lower the fee UpWork takes. The new structure is a flat 10 fee for all. I do think some contracts were taken outside of UpWork, which led to a reduction in the average spend per client which is reflected in the Gross service volume decline. I do think this is temporary, as with any price increase decision made.

The 0.46 in active clients they reported in 2024Q2 is not active clients in that quarter. But in the last 12 months. So I dont see a reason to think that is a seasonal effect. In 2023Q2 it was 0.6. In 2022Q2 it was 1.77. So basically what the number tells us is that they lost more clients in 2024Q2 than they won in 2023Q2. Still, the 6 active clients YoY look kinda good, so if those would be the only numbers we have QoQ and YoY, I would say I dont know what to think. Lets wait until next quarter. But we also have the guidance of 6 in revenue QoQ. The worst guidance in the history of UpWork. And they explain it with negative trends in the topoffunnel which could mean active clients or spent per client I think and expect it to continue We did see those trends get slightly worse in June and July And they talk about working on anticircumvention efforts in the call. You can find it in the transcript. Which should mean they will try to stop buyers and sellers from leaving the platform once they have found each other. Why would they have to do that if their users wanted to use the invoicing service they provide? The users dont want it. I dont think you can grow a business by saying We have a good service and a bad service. We give you a good service for a few days and then well force you to use our bad service forever.

The merits of combining mechanics and horoscopic astrology

Wtf is this nonsense?
Wow, thank you! Thats really cool feedback

I definitely feel that. Contrarian approaches can pay off. I dont have any evidence to this but it often does feel like mainstream stock picks come from a conflict of interest. Its like they want us to buy the news when we should be selling it. But every once in a while the prosperity of their picks endures.
I like looking at market cyclicality too. I like looking at it through the lens of game theory.

I stayed away from them intel because of their fundamentals qualitatively and their declining leadership. I chose to go with Nvidia just before ChatGPT dropped. I know that was a lot of luck. But I postulate that their established leadership and accelerating market share and brilliant management put them in the position to benefit from luck. Its like that old saying luck is where hard work and opportunity meet.. I cant really remember who said it and Im probably paraphrasing. I have multiple instances of anecdotal evidence that this is true. Basically where I entered positions into great companies just before the opportunity met their hard work. You could have also seen this if you were studying economic data and their managements choices.
Thank you and Sure thing!

Im loving your playful analogy! lol good stuff! Id say its more akin to mechanics and nautical science. My approach to technical analysis combines the study of crowd behavior, and whether fundamentals could allow the valuation to get to the projected possible outcomes. It also emphasizes the use of Bayesian probability. Science, math and technology often look like magic to the uninitiated. But hey to each is own. I also believe fundamental analysis alone can still yield great results.

Thanks for the feedback! I agree, my approach could be rather time intensive when you first start. It took me a while to get to the point where I can get my ongoing research done in 12 hours per day. Do you have any tactic or aspect of your investingtrading style that really defined it?
Not a fan? Do you mind expanding on that constructively? Do you want to share your approach to investing? I was hoping to spark discussion by expressing my approach the best I could in a brief way.

They mix in good picks to maintain some semblance of competence. Of course never assign malice for what could just be incompetence. Regardless its the contrarian life for me. There is no best strategy, however there are best strategies for individuals. Regardless the majority should stick with buying mostly ETFs based on SP500 and not attempt stocks individually. Did not mean to be overly flippant your post was fine, and you put effort into it.

Markets behave within a general spectrum and capitalizing on it is fairly easy. Of course black swans come in and thats where everyone gets burned. For real fuck RSI, look at how the broad market moves away from the 200 and go by percentages and back test it and you can see how overbought things were before a correction. Use this as a confirmation with all your other analysis that you are surely using.
I stopped trying to be perfect. An 85 solution was more than sufficient, and trying to get to 95 was more likely to result in paralysis than in optimal results. Good luck!

Dont expect a lot of fanfare. I do what you do and get downvoted all the time. I love seeing the cyclical buy ins when smart money and insiders buy and you can see usually bang on when the diversions hit in technical analysis. The other thing that I do is analyze how far in an uptrend price action flies up in exuberance away from the 200 and make my sell orders accordingly and buys of course. All of this is on a strong foundation of fundamental analysis. Without the fundamentals, technical analysis means literally nothing. I would say all technical analyzers would agree unless, of course, they are day traders and thats entirely different and not applicable to this style of trading.

There is no best strategy, however there are best strategies for individuals. This is so true. Every person will have the personality or cognitive habits that mesh well with a particular strategy that might not work out well for another. I also agree that ETFs based on the SP 500 are a best practice for most people. I think it takes an unparalleled enthusiasm towards the process for someone to benefit from stock picking and even more for market timing. You gotta love the process.
That sounds like a good use of mean reversion. Like you said Id need to compare to all the other signals for confirmation but I like this longer term signal.

I like this, no such thing as a perfect setup. Thats why I like using Bayesian probability. I think looking for a perfect deterministic setup can indeed cause too much hesitation. As long as youre hitting probabilities that allow for profit with your rewardrisk ratio then youre likely to make money over the long run.
I like what youre putting down my friend. Id love to hear more about this 200. Are you using Bollinger bands to give you perspective on this exuberance?

You are optimistic about peoples general ability. Im less so, at least 70 of all people would never be able to conceptualize applying any guidelines to new situationsstocks, the learned traits area of the brain is in direct space competitionright next to the section for conceptualizing. Of the 30 whos brains are wired for it how many can do it better then the market? The number becomes very low of the population very quickly. This sort of talk tends to piss people off for whatever reason. I had a few very simple questionsmetal puzzles during interview process that would let me know. owned an engineering firm Based on the results I would hire people without a degree over someone with a engineering degree. Innate abilityhow a person brain works cannot be taught. Flip side everyone I hired were the worst spellers with terrible grammar, smaller learned traits portion of the brain.
Yes I am unaware of a technical analysis tool that does this calculation so I do it manually from the highs and the lows off the average.

No just percentages away from the 200. You can see it like clockwork when it swings up too high with the usual vicissitudes and exuberance. Lets face it, you can do the same with the EPS daily or whatever but I prefer using the 200MDA. You can get a real feel for how overbought a stock is and make a reasonable assumption of a natural pullback.

I like your first principles approach here. I do agree that some people have significant cognitive advantages. They can learn quicker. They think faster. They have better analogical reasoning. Better pattern recognition. I recently had seen some anecdotal evidence to the contrary though. I know AI and human brains arent equally comparable, but I found this really intriguing. Open AIs ChatGPT has parameter counts rumored to be in the trillions and llama 3.1 has around 400 billion parameters. Even with this vast difference in size Im looking at this like brain power llama is competing quite well because they found that if they just spend way more time training the model it magnifies its ability. I think these findings are probably having an effect on the development of GPT5 or whatever they plan to name it. This leads me to hypothesize that anyone can do anything if you have enough time and effort. This still brings you to a fork in the road. How much value will you get for the extra time and effort put into learning the craft? I dont think this will change many employers minds but it could give confidence and motivation to people who want to improve themselves.

The general rules is anyone above 115IQ can learn any career. However I was not talking about IQ, just areas of the brain that helps with certain tasks. Nasa did a study many decades ago trying to find out why some of the smartest aerospace minds in the world could not spell aerospace. Brain scans revealed the space competing parts of the brains next to each other. The general rule is you cannot teach someone to be good at troubleshoot new things if they dont have that innate ability, its not a direct IQ indication but rather a brain thing. You have a method and can do it because that is how your brain works, thinking of a box in your mind one side of it is red, can you rotate the box in your mind and seeknow where the red side of the box is even when its on the otherside of your perspective eyes 70 of people cannot do that and you cannot teach them to do it.

I admit a might have a bias here. As I was reading your comment I was flipping around a box with a single red side in my head, simultaneously thinking Where is he going with this?. Then youre like 70 of people cant do this. Im like oh . But this is why people should go the SP 500 route long term and paper trade till they feel confident in what they are doing. Then run their plans by multiple financial advisors and experts before making any detrimental decisions that could affect their lifestyle. Even if someone never makes it out of paper trading I think its a rewarding experience. I think Im in love with the process as much as the end goal.

This is not a great sub for your question, due to the demographics and wildly disparate level of experience here. Your options for childrens investments are generally 529 plan for education Custodial UTMA brokerage account Parentowned standard brokerage account Custodial Roth IRA Since you already know about 529 plans, Ill skip that but please do your research on the Roth IRA rollover capability thats now available money is never locked up in these accounts. Lets focus on the others. A custodial taxable brokerage account can be opened with the child as a beneficiary and you as custodian. You can invest in stock index funds there see rBogleheads for index fund investing philosophy and steps extremely easy. A custodial account must legally transfer ownership to the child at age 1821 depending on your state You can also create a regular taxable account for yourself and simply earmark it for your child, gifting cash or shares at a future date at your discretion. A custodial Roth IRA should be opened when your child is a teen and gets their first job. Then you can contribute on their behalf up to the amount they earn, or the annual maximum at that time, whichever is less. Do not listen to people who tell you to count chores as earned income. Thats not allowed and the IRS is not stupid. Finally, do not save. You want to invest. Bank accounts, CDs, Treasury bonds, etc. are not ideal for the long term time horizon of a young child. Purchase equities so you can leverage the stock markets ongoing trend of long term growth.

You get to give 18k per spouse per donee each year without triggering an IRS gift tax or reducing your federal estate tax exemption. In other words, you transfer this money to your heirs with no taxes. Downside that someone pointed out in this thread is these assets can be counted against your child when applying for financial aid in college. We arent going to be eligible for that anyway, so this isnt a hang up for us.

Isnt Edward Jones a financial advisor firm? Isnt she paying them already? If they are fiduciaries lordy, I hope so for those rates then you already have someone you can talk to about this. Also, I understand the desire to minimize taxes, but remember that someone is going to pay taxes on that money in CB at some point. If you move it to a Roth, then its already taxed and she or her heirs can pull it taxfree. AND its not subject to RMDs. It might be reasonable to just do a Roth conversion for the CB money or several over a couple years depending on where she is in the tax and IRMAA brackets. Max out the tax bracket shes in and you can probably convert in a couple years without triggering unnecessary taxes or and IRMAA cliff. Lastly, you posted this in a couple places .. .might as well hit rretirement as well. That seems like your target audience.
Corebridge sells annuities. It is not the same as a brokerage account and probably has featuresbenefits that youre not familiar with.

She has to take out a few thousand every year bc shes over a certain age. Youre describing RMD required minimum distribution, from a retirement account? Yes, the government requires this and provides the table for how much to take, based on the FMV of the accounts at prior year end and the persons age, which I dont see where you told us this important piece of information. but I also dont want her to have to pay 20 tax on the money right away. Anything that is removed from a taxable retirement account, such as Trad IRA or 401k, is taxable as ordinary income. It may or may not be 20. There is withholding, which is deducted at the time of the distribution, for retirement accounts. Thats likely the 20 you mention, which is not Taxes. Its a prepayment against her 1040. a big chunk in a vanguard 20 and then I invested the other 19. Vanguard is a brokerage. Which funds? Invested the other 19 in what? A perspective of the mix helps. Shes a single, widow, head of household thats old enough to hit any qualifier for tax stuff. Shes retired. The 5y rule wouldnt apply to her, I know that. Yes, there are a number of 5year rules for Roth. Yes, the accountbased Roth IRA fiveyear rule says you cannot withdraw earnings taxfree until its been at least five years since you first contributed to a Roth IRA account. This fiveyear rule applies to everyone who contributes to a Roth IRA, whether theyre 59 12 or 105 years old. It will depend, then, and when she takes funds and how much as compared to her basis. From Yes, another Roth 5year rule is for conversions. Each carries its own 5year clock. She wont be subject to this rule. ideally some kind of welcome bonus even if its 150200 bucks You dont need a Bonus for retirement investing. You dont need to work on incentives. You just need to work on being helpful and getting her some lower risk with better performance. It isnt clear if CB is holding annuities for this person. That one of the investment types, and not an account, and thats why it matters to note the holdings. Yes, you would talk to the ED Jones person, but they are paid advisor group. You also can Rollover a Trad IRA to a Vanguard IRA this means Account and then investreinvest the holdings. You can do a direct trusteetotrustee transfer for the holdings, often in kind from a Trad IRA to a Roth IRA, but that is a taxable conversion. I do not recommend conversions unless the person is under 70 or really wont touch this money for 1015 years. Thats because they are already taking RMDs and paying taxes, so moving it and paying taxes, then needing to take some as distributions anyway, just churned their account a bit. And as pointed out, watch her income tax bracket, for triggering IRMAA. Thats an expensive lesson.

TLDR Early March 2020 Hesitated to invest in masks due to market chaos. A trusted supplier offered KN95 masks, leading to first order of 250,000 masks. Market was chaotic stories of buyers offering cash directly at factories. First order sold quickly, yielding 172,600 in profit. Second shipment 1 million masks sold, earning 1.57 million in profit. Third shipment 1.06 million masks and 20,000 gowns sold, adding 1.08 million in profit. Total profit from first three shipments 2.83 million. Fourth shipment 5.15 million masks planned, costing 11.12 million. U.S. government regulation and market collapse caused 5 million loss, wiping out previous profits. Overall, despite 13.87 million in total sales, ended with significant losses.

Good analysis. The little I know about development of systems following Functional Safety ISO26262 tells me that Tesla vision only AI design will never be able to proof level 5 autonomy. It is escalable true, but never safe enough to be approved on the roads.

Some minor details in need of correctionclarification. Radar and lidar are also capable of detecting and classifying pedestrians either by themselves or as part of a multimodal sensor suite. In fact they can be better than cameras in some circumstances, low light as you mentioned. Some lidars also give Dopplerrelative speed not sure if Waymos does but I know AURs does. Video processing is necessarily a much more resource intensive task than processing lidar or radar data. Now everyone I know that has radar and lidar also has cameras, so that may not be important but there are probably some optimizations that having multiple sensors allows a reduction in the amount of video that needs to be processed. Rapid iteration is not a differentiator, everyone doing self driving Waymo included can push updates whenever they want. Most also use Continuous integration pipelines. Regulatory hurdles are mostly propagandafake news auto companies self certify for safety, other than FMVSS rules which are testable requirements NHTSA can verify. FMVSS rules are very easy to comply with and say nothing about autonomy. There are some FMVSS changes required to remove steering wheel pedals and other things but those changes have been in process for years and should be done soon if it hasnt already happened, not familiar with the latest status. The easy work around is to simply not delete these until the rules change, theres also a waiver process that some companies I believe have successfully completed to delete these components. The real regulatory hurdle is liability, and needing to pay out millions in damages when a court determines your product killed someone and the manufacturer is liable. In other words the only real barrier is tech readiness. Regulatory hurdles are just an excuse that wallstreet types tend to buy.

Even if we agreed that theres power concerns, fiscal concerns, concerns with the overall model of AI, concerns about chip manufacturing and ability Its unlikely any of that is on the ballot on the 28th. These are longer term problems, so Id be more willing to bet they become an issue over the next 6 to 18 months rather than in 3 days. So its a pretty regarded take to make based on the thesis. TLDR If you want to make a macro AI thesis you should put the time frame for it to play out at longer than 3 days. More like 618 months.

Buy post puts or gtfo. I read 1 paragraph of the DD before giving up. But GPT read and responded in 5seconds The critique youve provided rests on a few misconceptions and overlooks key aspects of AIs current trajectory and potential. 1. AI Approaches and Progress The critique dismisses the GPTML approach as a known dead end, but this perspective fails to account for the significant advancements these methods have already achieved. While its true that current AI systems are not equivalent to human intelligence or capable of fulfilling science fictionlike fantasies e.g., J.A.R.V.I.S., this was never their immediate goal. The successes of GPT3, GPT4, and similar models in natural language processing, image generation, and other domains are impressive and provide immense value across industries. 2. Exponential Investment for Linear Gains The notion of exponential investment for linear gains is not unique to AI. Most technological progress, particularly in nascent fields, requires substantial investment before significant breakthroughs are realized. The idea that AI is stagnating is contradicted by ongoing improvements in model capabilities, optimization techniques, and the emergence of new architectures that continue to push the boundaries of whats possible. 3. Business Case for AI The critique argues that AI has failed to meet investor expectations by not delivering a fully autonomous system capable of complex tasks like designing cars. However, this expectation misunderstands the nature of AI development. AI is not meant to be an allencompassing solution to every problem overnight. Incremental improvements, such as automating specific tasks, enhancing decisionmaking, and creating new products, are already transforming industries. The ultimate goals may be ambitious, but the journey itself is valuable and profitable. 4. Training Data and Resources Concerns about running out of training data or resources ignore the adaptability of AI research. Techniques like transfer learning, unsupervised learning, and more efficient model architectures help mitigate these challenges. Moreover, the development of specialized hardware, improved algorithms, and better data utilization strategies continuously address the resourceintensive nature of AI. 5. Nvidias Role While its true that tech giants are moving towards vertical integration, Nvidia remains a critical player in the AI hardware ecosystem. The dominance of CUDA, the ongoing innovation in GPU architecture, and the importance of a robust softwarehardware ecosystem are not easily replaced or replicated. Nvidias role may evolve, but it is far from obsolete. 6. Investor Expectations The critique implies that investors are disillusioned, yet the continued flow of capital into AI suggests otherwise. While there may be some adjustments as the field matures, the broader trajectory of AI investment remains strong, driven by both immediate applications and longterm potential. In summary, while AIs development is complex and requires tempered expectations, dismissing the entire field as a bubble fails to appreciate the genuine advancements and ongoing potential that AI, particularly machine learning, continues to unlock.

Microsofts Phi 3.5 mini came out last week and has 3.8B parameters. It outperforms Llama 2 70B from a year ago on benchmarks. Thats almost 20x less parameters and possibly training time. They did this by improving training methodology and making training data higher quality. So methodology is leading to huge improvements. Hyper scale companies are continuing to scale wide AND implement these methodologies. This means each generation is getting better and better and we have a while before we get to scraping the bottom of the barrel of the gains.

The Jarvis is ridiculous only sounds silly if youve started paying attention to this in the last year or two. You can look up what folks like Sam Altman were saying 5 years ago. Here he is in 2019 openly saying they have no real path to profitability and once we make AI good enough itll just tell us how to make a return. A year ago the entire field was bristling with excitement about AGI and superintelligence, its a relatively recent development that theyve walked expectations back. Theyre just doing the fusion power is 5 years away thing. Heres Sam himself talking down GPT4 2 months before it came out and a couple months ago saying its mildly embarrassing at best and heres him saying largely the same thing nearly 6 years ago The current thing is always good enough for some tasks and the true AGI future is just a few years away. The issue isnt that it takes time, the issue is in 2020 when they released GPT3 theyd raised less than 100m, and today theyve raised over 13B, and they dont have a lot to show for that extra 12.9B. Sams talking about burning 50 billion a year to build AGI and its just got people wondering how many rounds well have to go on this before we get whats actually promised. At the end of the day its not his 50 billion to burn, his company isnt profitable so its gotta come from other people who arent going to keep ponying up if theres no progress to show for it. Obviously the AI sector is bigger than OpenAI, but theyre the best example. True AGI would be worth near infinite investment, but 400B for the current state of AI wasnt worth it, the longer this goes the more investors will just see it as throwing good money after bad.

Im too greedy and I believe there is much bigger gains to be had... why is the cyber truck a disaster? Its been the best seelling EV truck of the year so far granted theyre just getting through the preorder backlog, but people are still completing their orders I have also been seeing them everywhere in person and also everyone around me is constantly mentioning it or talking about it. Positive things and negative, tbh mostly negative but imo no news is bad news the more people that hate on it the more people will eventually find it and like it, the haters dont realize theyre only contributing to its success. Everyone is making videos or talking about it constantly and you can look at any celebrity and they all seem to have one. self driving cars already exist with companies like Waymo, tesla is not far behind. Watch some videos of the newest version of their FSD and youll see how advanced it already is. It can gauge complex situations like accidents or animals running in the road and is often driving better than many humans I know. yes there are companies who are selling real robo taxi services right now one of which being waymo. But if you see the difference of what theyve completed compared to what Tesla is achieving you would be surprised. The current existing robo taxis have tens of thousands of dollars of sensors on them and are geofenced to small mapped out areas. Tesla is selling their vehicles for less than the sensors alone on those vehicles and teslas will eventually have nongeofences full self driving. The calculations are being done in real time by AI trained on hundreds of thousands of hours of real time driving footage from real people. Once completed a Tesla will be able to encounter any road, any situation, anywhere and solve it where as the other companies are focused on tiny areas just to get it working. Thats not to put down what theyve done or say it doesnt have its place but Tesla is aiming for something on a much greater scale and once completed will most likely take over the entire market.

2035 is a ways away so it is hard to try and predict what will happen. Regardless of the speedbumps along the way, I see an eventual full transition to electric or at least 90 of vehicles on the road. Not to say we wont have major issues to deal with, I could also see the mandates getting rolled back in certain states. The goal of the electric car is to never have to think about charging it, eventually, everyone will change at home when they go to bed, so why would you want to go somewhere to fill up? The only time most people will be charging away from home will be over long distances which is what superchargers are for and eventually battery tech will improve, we already have comparable ranges to ICE vehicles. The new model 3 long range gets 363 which is more than my small Toyota. The 38 revenue from carbon credits is just from a recent quarter most likely because they have a backlog of them and this is a rough time for sales so they need to claim them in order to help prop up the business while theyre suffering. Tesla will survive long term. The vehicle sector of tesla is definetly the most prominent portion currently, but long term it will not be. That is why they market themselves as a technology company, they ened ot sell the cars to people first for them to want to purchase FSD eventually once it gets better. Having an EV will lead them down the road into Tesla energy by having battery walls installed or solar tiles on their roofs. The energy sector profits more than doubled last quarter for tesla, this is the beginning of the transition of profits into other sectors. Teslas are already cheap enough a new model 3 costs about the same as a toyota corolla, not to say 26k is cheap by any means. I definetly wouldnt buy one new but a lot of people would the F150 is the most popular vehicle in america and costs 45k. People will be happy to switch once they learn about the benefits, right now there is a lot of boomer hate against sustainable things and EVs and that will change as the young generations take over and become wealthy and settled into thei rjobs and can make the transition. In 20 years kids wont believe that cars used to run on gas and didnt drive themsleves.

Rivian is also a company I am interested In but their prospects are limited in comparison. No charging network, no self driving, no energy sector, no robots. Rivian is solely an EV company which is not a bad thing but its growth opportunities will be limited, especially considering how much of the EV market is already dominated by Tesla. Not to mention they are losing money and running out of time...
